A classic that everyone should own.

If you never played the Portal series, then you probably do not know what Valve's absolute best game-series is before they stopped being game-makers and became game-distributors.

Gameplay is up there! The game's story, while rudimentary, is somehow managing to be a strong-point, especially with the second game - where the introduction of a second "character" kicks it up a notch. Generally speaking: Portal 2 takes a solid gameplay-idea and builds an even more compelling experience around it. 
While the environments in Portal 1 come across as minimalist and a bit spartan, Portal 2's graphics seem to age quite well, lots more production-value and content in the second title - but that should not stop you from beginning your yourney in the first one. 

Other games may be better head-turners, these two have the capacity of making your head explode from within. Food for brains, less so for brawns.

Very creative game.

It makes you think outside the box. 10/10

Only 3 hours played at the time of this review.

The initial story doesn't take long to complete. It's quite a short game, but there are some bonus levels to be unlocked with a harder difficulty. Extremely satisfying to figure out the different puzzles. They start out appropriately easy, then progressively become more complex. 

Although the game was only $9.99 at full price, I waited for a sale to actually purchase at $0.99. I would absolutely say I got my moneys worth, even with a shorter story. I'm not sure how I would've felt paying full price, but I can't imagine being disappointed. The replay value is very high.

Portal, in general, is a very fun First-Person Puzzle game with intuitive movement and a gameplay mechanic that (at it's time) had never been created before, or has been effectively replicated since. Gameplay almost always consists of finding the right place to put a certain object and using your portals to move that object to the right spot. Specifically energy balls and Aperture Science Weighted Storage Cubes. (There is also the ever-infamous Aperture Science Weighted Companion Cube, that plagued the internet for years after the game came out.) For it's time, it's held up surprisingly well. Playing it now is just as fun as I'm sure it was when it came out, and a game I think anybody who is a fan of puzzle games should play.
